citing_paper_authors: Lu, Wang | Claire, Cardie
raw_text: We are also interested in understanding whether, and which, linguistic features of the discussion are important for dispute detection. Drawing inspiration from studies of human mediation of on line conflicts (e.g. Billings and Watts (2010), Kittur et al (2007), Kraut and Resnick (2012)), we hypothesize that effective methods for dispute detection should take into account the sentiment and opinions expressed by participants in the collaborative endeavor
clean_text: We are also interested in understanding whether, and which, linguistic features of the discussion are important for dispute detection. Drawing inspiration from studies of human mediation of on line conflicts (e.g. Billings and Watts (2010), Kittur et al (2007), Kraut and Resnick (2012)), we hypothesize that effective methods for dispute detection should take into account the sentiment and opinions expressed by participants in the collaborative endeavor.

citing_paper_authors: Lu, Wang | Claire, Cardie
raw_text: We also compare with two state-of-the-art methods that are used in sentiment prediction for conversations: (1) an SVM (RBF kernel) that is employed for identifying sentiment-bearing sentences (Hassan et al, 2010), and (dis) agreement detection (Yin et al, 2012) in on line debates; (2) a Linear CRF for (dis) agreement identification in broadcast conversations (Wang et al, 2011)
clean_text: We also compare with two state-of-the-art methods that are used in sentiment prediction for conversations: (1) an SVM (RBF kernel) that is employed for identifying sentiment-bearing sentences (Hassan et al, 2010), and (dis) agreement detection (Yin et al, 2012) in on line debates; (2) a Linear CRF for (dis) agreement identification in broadcast conversations (Wang et al, 2011).

raw_text: Task 2 of the CoNLL-2010 Conference Shared Task (Farkas et al, 2010b) proposed solving the problem of in-sentence hedge cue phrase identi 38fication and scope detection in two different domains (biological publications and Wikipediaarticles), based on manually annotated corpora
clean_text: Task 2 of the CoNLL-2010 Conference Shared Task (Farkas et al, 2010b) proposed solving the problem of in-sentence hedge cue phrase identification and scope detection in two different domains (biological publications and Wikipedia articles), based on manually annotated corpora.

citing_paper_authors: Guillermo, Moncecchi | Jean-Luc, Minel | Dina, Wonsever
raw_text: The best result on hedge cue identification (Tanget al, 2010) obtained an F-score of 81.3 using a supervised sequential learning algorithm to learn BIOclasses from lexical and shallow parsing information, also including certain linguistic rules
clean_text: The best result on hedge cue identification (Tanget al, 2010) obtained an F-score of 81.3 using a supervised sequential learning algorithm to learn BIOclasses from lexical and shallow parsing information, also including certain linguistic rules.

citing_paper_authors: Guillermo, Moncecchi | Jean-Luc, Minel | Dina, Wonsever
raw_text: For scope detection, Morante et al (2010) obtained an F-score of 57.3, using also a sequence classification approach for detecting boundaries (tagged in FOL format, where the first token of the span is marked with an F, while the last one is marked with an L)
clean_text: For scope detection, Morante et al (2010) obtained an F-score of 57.3, using also a sequence classification approach for detecting boundaries (tagged in FOL format, where the first token of the span is marked with an F, while the last one is marked with an L).

citing_paper_authors: Guillermo, Moncecchi | Jean-Luc, Minel | Dina, Wonsever
raw_text: Similarly, Kilicoglu and Bergler (2010) used a pure rule-based approach based on constituent parse trees in addition to syntactic dependency relations, and achieved the fourth best F score for scope detection, and the highest precision of the whole task (62.5)
clean_text: Similarly, Kilicoglu and Bergler (2010) used a pure rule-based approach based on constituent parse trees in addition to syntactic dependency relations, and achieved the fourth best F score for scope detection, and the highest precision of the whole task (62.5).

Finally, to compare our results with state-of-the art methods (even though that was not the main objective of the study), we used the corpus of de CoNLL 2010 Shared Task to train and evaluate our classifiers, using the best configurations found in the evaluation corpus, and obtained competitive results in both subtasks of Task 2

citing_paper_authors: Erik, Velldal | Jonathon, Read
raw_text: The shared task at the 2010 Conference on Natural Language Learning (CoNLL) focused on speculation detection for the domain of biomedical research literature (Farkas et al, 2010), with data sets based on the BioScopecorpus (Vincze et al, 2008) which annotates so called speculation cues along with their scopes
clean_text: The shared task at the 2010 Conference on Natural Language Learning (CoNLL) focused on speculation detection for the domain of biomedical research literature (Farkas et al, 2010), with data sets based on the BioScope corpus (Vincze et al, 2008) which annotates so called speculation cues along with their scopes.
